title.value: ConceptGraphs: Open-Vocabulary 3D Scene Graphs for Perception and Planning
title.justification: The title precisely describes the primary contribution of the paper, which is the ConceptGraphs method.
title.quote: ConceptGraphs: Open-Vocabulary 3D Scene Graphs for Perception and Planning

extractions.description: The paper proposes ConceptGraphs, a novel method to construct open-vocabulary and object-centric 3D scene graphs for robot perception and planning. It leverages 2D foundation models and fuses their outputs into 3D by multiview association to create a structured and semantically rich representation. The method allows robots to understand complex scenes, perform task planning, and handle abstract language queries without requiring large 3D datasets or model finetuning.

type.justification: The paper includes experiments and real-world trials with robots to validate the proposed method, which classifies it as an empirical study.
type.quote: We implement and demonstrate ConceptGraphs on a number of real-world robotics tasks across wheeled and legged mobile robot platforms.

name.justification: The research involves using deep learning models for building 3D scene representations from 2D image data.
name.quote: Recent approaches have attempted to leverage features from large vision-language models to encode semantics in 3D representations.

name.justification: The paper focuses on 3D scene graphs which are an advanced representation for understanding the spatial relationships and semantic information in 3D scenes.
name.quote: ConceptGraphs, a 3D scene representation method for robot perception and planning that satisfies all the above requirements.

name.justification: The model is used for segmentation in the proposed ConceptGraphs method.
name.quote: We use SegmentAnything (SAM) [33] as the segmentation model Seg(Â·).

name.justification: The model extracts visual features for the segmented regions.
name.quote: Each extracted mask mt,i is then passed to a visual feature extractor (CLIP [31], DINO [53]) to obtain a visual descriptor ft,i = Embed(Itrgb , mt,i ).

name.justification: The model is used alongside CLIP for feature extraction from segmented regions.
name.quote: Each extracted mask mt,i is then passed to a visual feature extractor (CLIP [31], DINO [53]) to obtain a visual descriptor ft,i = Embed(Itrgb , mt,i ).

name.justification: LLaVA is used for generating object captions from visual data.
name.quote: We use LLaVA [55] as the vision-language model LVLM and GPT-4 [32] for our LLM.

name.justification: GPT-4 is used as the language model for inferring relationships and processing language queries.
name.quote: We use LLaVA [55] as the vision-language model LVLM and GPT-4 [32] for our LLM.

name.justification: The model is used in a variant of the ConceptGraphs system for open-vocabulary detection.
name.quote: An open-vocabulary 2D detector (Grounding DINO [34]) to obtain object bounding boxes.

name.justification: The dataset is used to evaluate the accuracy of 3D scene graphs generated by ConceptGraphs.
name.quote: For each scene in the Replica dataset [56], we report scene graph accuracy metrics for both CG and the detector-variant CG-D.

name.justification: Used for building initial pointcloud maps for the Jackal robot navigation.
name.quote: The initial Jackal pointcloud does not include task-relevant objects and is downprojected to a 2D costmap for navigation using the base Jackal ROS stack.

name.justification: Utilized for obtaining camera poses and the scene point cloud in experiments.
name.quote: We then stage two separate scenes with different objects: one for object search and another for traversability estimation. In both cases, we map the scene with an Azure Kinect Camera and rely on RTAB-Map [69] to obtain camera poses and the scene point cloud.
